audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 17 and Unit 18.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 17 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Stone Soup.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sound.
<visual: articulation video for /ô/ sound>

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the /ô/ sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/ôôôlll/, all. /tôôôlll/, tall. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table for /ô/>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about raising money for good causes. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. lemonade stand <pause>, cup <pause>, sign <pause>, pitcher <pause>, money. Look at the lemonade stand in the picture. What do you think these children are doing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about raising money for good causes. The word is purchase. When people purchase something, they buy it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, purchase>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, donate>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Raising Money for Good Causes”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words purchase and donate>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about raising money for good causes? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this story is "Walking for a Cause.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Walking for a Cause. This story is about a boy who wants to support a cause, or an organization he believes in.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: charity. A charity is a group or organization that helps people or animals in need. A charity might give food to help animals in a shelter. How could someone raise money for a charity that helps people in their community?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, charity>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the name of the main character.
What is Paul’s plan to help the food bank? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How is a food bank a charity? How does a food bank make a difference in a community?
What kind of charity would you be willing to support? Why?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about why it is important to support charities that help people in need. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Final, and Medial Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Walking for a Cause.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Final, and Medial Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: call
Say the word call, but change the beginning sound. Change /k/, to /b/. What's the new word? <pause> ball
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: hard
Say the word hard, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> heart
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: sat
Say the word sat, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ē/. What's the new word? <pause> seat
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the /ô/ sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/ôôôlll/, all. /tôôôlll/, tall. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: music, night, old, picture, sentence>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word music. Say the word with me. Music. Which sounds do you hear in Music? /m/ /yo͞o/ zik. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: m-u-s-i-c. The word "music" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: night, old, picture, sentence.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about underwater art museums. First, look at these three picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Mexico <pause>, diver <pause>, sculpture <pause>, statue <pause>, Grenada. Look at the statue in the picture. How do you think people visit this statue?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about underwater art museums. The word is lessen. Lessen means “to reduce or become smaller.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, lessen>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, unique>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Underwater Art Museums”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words lessen and unique>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about underwater art museums? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this text is "Coral Reefs: A Call to Action.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Coral Reefs: A Call to Action. This text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue for a story. A coral reef is a large structure under the water made up of sea creatures called corals.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: threatened. Threatened means “put in danger.” The forest fire threatened the plants and animals that live there. What can happen to plants and animals whose homes are threatened for too long?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, threatened>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the phrase that tells where divers go to see coral reefs.
What is the connection between polyps and coral reefs? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the world’s coral reefs being threatened, or put in danger?
If the prefix re- means “again,” what does regrowing mean? How can regrowing coral in nurseries help coral reefs that have been damaged?
Why do you think the author included the subtitle “A Call to Action”? How does the author encourage readers to take action?
What other questions do you have about coral reefs? How could you find answers to them?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of three to five facts that you learned about coral reefs. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Coral Reefs: A Call to Action.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the /ô/ sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with al.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with aw.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word pat. <pause> Change the letter t to w. What word did you make? Paw
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word pat<pause>. Now change pat to paw. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with variant vowel /ô/ and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with variant vowel /ô /. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word daughter. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word daughter>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: all/walk, saw/crawl.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs all/walk, saw/crawl>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.

Let's review syllable types. Vowel team syllables are syllables that contain a vowel team. The vowel team always stays together in the same syllable. Listen as I say the following word: "draw." What is the vowel team that makes the /ô/ sound in "draw?"
The vowel team "a-w" makes /ô/ sound in "draw."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word draw and the phonics card aw below it>

audio.transcription: Some vowel teams include the letter "w" or "y," which can be both a consonant or a part of a vowel team. These common vowel teams include "a-w," "o-w," "a-y," and "e-y."
Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can read longer words by breaking them into syllables.
The word drawing has two syllables. "Draw" <pause> "ing." The vowel team "a-w" stays in the same syllable. Read each syllable aloud then blend the syllables to read the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word drawing broken up into two cards draw and ing>

audio.transcription: Let's break the word "seesaw" up into syllables.
Seesaw has two syllables. "See" <pause> "saw." Each syllable has a vowel team spelling. Read each syllable aloud then blend the syllables to read the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word seesaw broken up into two cards see and saw>

audio.transcription: Practice segmenting the following words into syllables. <pause> Then identify the vowel team syllable in each word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words because, beanstalk, baseball, cutest, higher, and flowing>

audio.transcription: This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: spell, thought, together, while, world.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word spell. Say the word with me. Spell. Which sounds do you hear in spell? /s/ /p/ /e/ /l/. Blend the sounds together. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: s-p-e-l-l. Say the word, spell.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: thought, together, while, world.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word fall.
Now write the word talk.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
saw
straw
mall
small
walking
yawning

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this text is "Water, Water." Point to each word as you read the title with me: Water, Water. This is a poem. The text is formatted in short lines in groups of four instead of paragraphs. Read the poem. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the poem with variant vowel /ô/ spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: I thought we could walk to the mall. Say the sentence with me: I thought we could walk to the mall. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: He will mow the lawn while I talk to Dawn. Say the sentence with me: He will mow the lawn while I talk to Dawn. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Water, Water.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Let's review syllables with vowel teams. Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team always stays together in the same syllable. The words "crawling," "alright," and "always" all have vowel team syllables.
The word crawling has two syllables. "crawl" <pause> "ing." The vowel team "aw" stays together in the first syllable <pause> "crawl."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word crawling and and separate syllables crawl / ing and show the vowel team in red font>

audio.transcription: The word alright has two syllables. "al" <pause> "right." The vowel team "igh" stays together in the second syllable <pause> "right."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word alright and the separate syllables al / right and show the vowel team in red font>

audio.transcription: The word always has two syllables. "al" <pause> "ways." The vowel team "ay" stays together in the second syllable <pause> "ways."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word always and the separate syllables al / ways and show the vowel team in red font>

audio.transcription: Practice identifying the vowel team syllable in each of the following words and dividing the word into syllables.

Look at these words. Let's read the words together: cause, author, haul, saucer, crawl, draw, straw, hawk, stall, wallet, bald, always. Now look at these two categories. This is the word stall. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put stall under? <pause> Yes, stall goes in the al category because the word is spelled with al. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
What did you notice about the words in each group?
"Au," aw," and "al" are common spellings. You may notice the au, aw, and al spellings in many words. As we read, let's look for words with au, aw, and al.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about dams. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Colorado River <pause>, Hoover Dam <pause>, reservoir. Look at the Hoover Dam in the picture. What do you think the purpose of a dam is?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about dams. The word is barriers. Barriers are obstacles, or walls, that block movement.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, barriers>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, altered>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Rethinking Dams”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words barriers and altered>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about dams? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this text is "Who Do You Agree With?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Who Do You Agree With? You will read two opinions about this statement: Water should be free for everyone.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: opposing. Opposing means “opposite, or contrasting.” People have opposing views about the best way to stop pollution. When was a time when you and a friend had opposing views about something? What did you do?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, opposing>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names something in our homes that can leak water.
Why does the boy think water should be free? Find sentences that answer this question.
How can you tell the girl has an opposing, or opposite, view? What reasons does she give to support her argument?
Which side presented a more convincing argument? Why do you think this?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw two columns on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write one opinion about water use at the top of each column and list reasons and examples from the text below each one. <pause> Use this information to write a two or three sentence summary of the text. <pause> Share your summary with a partner before writing. Then you'll state whether or not you think water should be free for all people.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Sounds in Blends

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Who Do You Agree With?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Sounds in Blends

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: bend
Say the word bend, but change /d/ to /ch/. What's the new word? <pause> bench
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the second sound in a word. Listen as I say a word: glue
Say the word glue, but change /l/ to /r/. What's the new word? <pause> grew
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: music, night, old, picture, sentence, spell, thought, together, while, world.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word music. Say the word with me: "night"

Spell the word with me: n-i-g-h-t. Say the word with me. Night. Which sounds do you hear in spell? /n/ /ī/ /t/. Blend the sounds together. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: night, old, picture, sentence, spell, thought, together, while, world.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards to build words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with variant vowel /ô/ spellings and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with variant vowel /ô/ spellings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word talking. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word talking>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: call/talk, chalk/draw.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs call/talk, chalk/draw>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: old, music, night, picture, sentence, spell, thought, together, while, world.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word old. Say the word with me: "old"
Spell the word with me: o-l-d. The word "old" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: music, night, picture, sentence, spell, thought, together, while, world.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. old, <pause> music, <pause> night, <pause> picture, <pause> sentence, <pause> spell, <pause> thought, <pause> together, <pause> while, <pause> world.
audio.notes: <visual: show "old, music, night, picture, sentence, spell, thought, together, while, world" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word, old]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "At night I can see ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "At night I can see [blank].">

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this text is "Causes of Water Pollution." Point to the word as you read the title with me: Causes of Water Pollution. This text lists ways that water becomes polluted. It includes a diagram with labels and arrows. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the diagram?
Create a diagram that shows another cause-and-effect relationship, such as a common way water is wasted.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Causes of Water Pollution.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Let's review syllable types. Vowel team syllables are syllables that contain a vowel team. The vowel team always stays together in the same syllable. Listen as I say the following word: "saw." Which vowel team makes the /ô/ sound in "saw?"
The vowel team "aw" makes /ô/ sound in "saw."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word saw and the phonics card aw below it>

audio.transcription: The letter "w," which is found in words like "wall" and "walk," can also be a part of a vowel team.
Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can read longer words by breaking them into syllables.
The word "sawdust" has two syllables. "saw" <pause> "dust." The vowel team "aw" stays together in the same syllable. Read each syllable aloud then blend the syllables to read the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word sawdust broken up into two cards saw and dust>

audio.transcription: Let's break the word "relaunch" up into syllables.
Relaunch has two syllables. "Re" <pause> "launch." The vowel team "au" stays together in the same syllable. Read each syllable aloud then blend the syllables to read the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word relaunch broken up into two cards re and launch>

audio.transcription: Practice segmenting the following words into syllables. <pause> Then identify the vowel team syllable in each word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words outlaw, snowball, earring, redrawing, and yawning>

audio.transcription: This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ô/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with aw.
Now, let's put a box around with au.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word jam. <pause>. Change the letter m to w to make the /ô/ spelling. What word did you make? Jaw
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word jam<pause>. Now change jam to jaw. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a story about Rapunzel. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Rapunzel <pause>, sky <pause>, prince <pause>, hair <pause>, tower. Look at the prince in the picture. What is he using to climb the tower?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about Rapunzel. The word is invented. Invented means “created or made up.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, invented>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, unusual>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Rapunzel - A German Fairy Tale”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words invented and unusual>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about Rapunzel? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this story is "Rumpelstiltskin.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Rumpelstiltskin. You will read a fairy tale about a character who can change straw into gold.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: despair. Despair means “feeling lost and without hope.” Dad looked for his lost phone in despair. What is something that might make you feel despair if you lost it?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, despair>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names what the girl must use to make gold.
What does the small man offer to do? What must the girl give him in return? Find the sentences that answer the questions.
What two events cause the girl to be filled with despair, or hopelessness? How does she overcome each problem?
What other fairy tales have you read or heard? Which story is your favorite? Why?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. Label the details, such as miller’s daughter, Rumpelstiltskin, straw, spinning wheel, gold, king, baby. <pause> Use your drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Rumpelstiltskin.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the Sound-Spelling Card for /ô/. The letter "a" by itself can stand for the /ô/ sound. The letter "a" can also work as team with other letters to make the /ô/ sound. The /ô/ sound can be spelled with "a," "a-w," "a-u," and "a-l."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for variant vowel /ô/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word lawn.
Now write the word falling.
Finally, write this sentence: We walked together down the hall.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about dinosaurs having feathers. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. dinosaur <pause>, tail <pause>, feathers <pause>, claws <pause>, teeth. Look at the dinosaur in the picture. What do you notice about the dinosaur?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about dinosaurs having feathers. The word is examine. When you examine something, you look at it closely and carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, examine>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, records>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Did Dinosaurs Have Feathers?”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words examine and records>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about dinosaurs having feathers? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 18 Student Book. The title of this story is "The Legend of the Talking Feather.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Legend of the Talking Feather. A legend is a story from the past that has been passed down over time. It is often about someone who really lived, but the facts of that person’s life in the story can’t be proven true. This legend features three birds instead of people: a hawk, a crow, and an eagle.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: courteous. Courteous means “acting in a polite way, or showing respect for others.“ It is courteous to keep your mouth closed when you eat, and cover your nose when you sneeze. What are some ways you are courteous? How do you feel when people around you are not being courteous? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, courteous>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that tells what Crow and Hawk are doing that makes so much noise.
How can you tell Crow and Hawk are arguing? Find the words and phrases that answer the question.
How can you tell Crow and Hawk are not acting in a courteous, or polite, way? How does Eagle show them how to act with respect toward each other?
What rules do we have at school to remind us to be courteous? Why is it important to treat each other with respect?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Extend the story by writing a new scene with Crow and Hawk using the talking feather. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 18, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 18.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 18 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Legend of the Talking Feather.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: fau-cet
Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. fau-cet, faucet.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: father
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Father, fa-ther.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Let's review syllables with vowel teams. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words. Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team always stays together in the same syllable.
The word beachball has two syllables. "beach" <pause> "ball." The vowel team "ea" stays together in the first syllable <pause> "beach."
Practice dviding the following words into syllables and identifying the vowel team syllable.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This word names something you wear on your head
Add one letter to hat to name a word that means stop.
Change one letter in halt to name the area outside classrooms at a school.
Change one letter in hall to name where you would hang a picture.
Change one letter in wall to name how you should cross a street.
Change the beginning of walk to name something you might use to draw.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "old."
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 18!
